Award.AwardTitle: FASEB Conference on "From Unfolded Proteins in the Endoplasmic Reticulum to Disease"

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching objective of the project is to integrate research, education and training by strongly encouraging the active participation of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in all aspects of a FASEB Summer Research Conference. The FASEB conference on the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) was established in 2007 to fill a critical need for an ER focused research conference. This FASEB Conference will bring together an international research community that investigates the structure, function and regulation of the endoplasmic reticulum. The conference will expose early career scientists to a broad range of experimental systems and approaches that are being used by the leading laboratories in this research field. Conference attendees are strongly encouraged to submit poster session abstracts. In addition to the thirty invited speakers, twelve additional speakers will be selected for "late breaking talks" based upon their submitted poster abstracts, giving strong preference for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. A critical objective of this FASEB conference is to stimulate discussion and the exchange of information between the established leaders in the field and early career scientists during all sessions of the meeting including the platform talks, meet the speaker sessions, and career development workshops. The FASEB summer conference on the endoplasmic reticulum is a critical driving force for the application of new technologies, development of novel concepts and fostering research collaborations between investigators with complementary expertise. Achieving the objectives of this project is critical to maintain the viability of this research field by promoting broader participation in the ER field and the development of the next generation of ER researchers.


This multi-disciplinary meeting brings together a diverse international community of biochemists, cell biologists, molecular biologists, geneticists and physiologists who investigate protein homeostasis in the endoplasmic reticulum. The conference is focused on elucidating the mechanisms for biosynthesis; processing and folding of proteins in the ER; protein quality control mechanisms that discriminate between folded and misfolded proteins; ER stress response pathways that allow the cell to alleviate protein-misfolding stress; and the ER associated degradation pathway that protects cells from the toxic accumulation of unfolded protein aggregates in the ER. While there has been tremendous progress in this research field, there remain critical knowledge gaps that can now be addressed using experimental methods that were not previously available and by cross-disciplinary approaches to synergistically expand knowledge in this research field. The conference platform sessions in the morning and evening will feature the invited speakers as well as the late breaking talks, with sufficient time allocated for discussion. Meet the speaker sessions at lunch, career development workshops in the early afternoon and poster sessions in the late afternoon will facilitate interactions between meeting attendees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FASEB Science Research Conference "The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Conference: from Unfolded Proteins to Disease" was a very successful conference that brought together an international group of 92 scientists to discuss recent research progress in the endoplasmic reticulum research field.  Of the 92 conferees, 43 had not attended this conference previously.  31 of the attendees were trainees, and 21 were early career faculty. Twelve early career scientists (graduate students and postdoctoral fellows) that are training in laboratories in the Unites States received the travel awards ($750/person) that were funded by the NSF grant.   

Intellectual merit: The goal of the 2019 FASEB ER conference was to communicate recent research findings in the endoplasmic reticulum research field. Throughout the conference there were typically five talks in each of the eight sessions, with 3-4 invited speakers per session.  The topics of the meeting addressed the following areas: translocation, processing and folding of proteins in the ER, ER stress response pathways, protein degradation in the ER (ERAD), ER associated protein misfolding diseases, ER morphology and dynamics. There were 29 oral presentations, 49 submitted abstracts for poster presentations with 13 “Late breaking talks” assigned based on abstracts submitted, mainly by trainees or junior faculty. All talks including the late-breaking talks were twenty minutes, plus 5 minutes for discussion.

Impact and outcome of the meeting:

Dr. Tom Rapoport set the stage for the conference with his keynote lecture entitled "The mechanism of ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD)" the first night of the conference. The talk raised a number of unanswered questions that lead to lively discussions that continued throughout the week.  Highlights of the talks included Dr. Julie Hollien (University of Utah), who discussed how degradation of Blos1 mRNA helps protect cells from ER stress, Dr. Peter Arvan (University of Michigan) who presented results indicating that aberrant disulfide bond formation of proinsulin is an early event in the progression of type II diabetes, Dr. Christine Mayr (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center) who described her research on the ER-associated TIS granules which are composed of specific mRNAs, and Russell Debose-Boyd (UT-Southwestern) who described new findings about ERAD mediated regulation of HMG CoA reductase. The meeting also included talks branching from basic ER biology into areas of physiology and pathophysiology, including obesity and metabolism, glaucoma, and viral infection, among others. The new information presented in the talks and posters made the conference very exciting and informative. FASEB sent a survey to all attendees to solicit their opinions about the program, the venue, and to request suggestions for future conferences. Feedback was extremely positive, with all scientific aspects of the meeting rating >4 on a scale of 1-5. The attendees mentioned that they had learned a lot and had gotten insights into their own research. Comments included “This was the most productive conference I have ever attended,” and “The quality of the talks and posters were very good and the conference organizers fostered a friendly atmosphere.”

Broader Impacts:

As many of the attendees and invited speakers had not attended this conference previously, the speakers brought fresh perspectives to the conference. Intellectual cross-fertilization was an important goal for the conference, and we were able to achieve this goal by attracting scientists with diverse expertise.  Several collaborations were initiated as an outcome of the conference.

One of the most important goals of the conference was to impact the training of early career scientists including graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.  The travel awards which were supported by the NSF award allowed these early career scientists to attend and participate in the conference. The recipients of the travel awards presented posters in the poster sessions and included six of the twelve recipients were selected for late breaking talks.  Each day there were also “Meet the Experts” sessions for trainees to meet the invited speakers, and discuss their research during lunch. A group of senior investigators served as moderators for the two career development sessions that occurred on Monday and Tuesday afternoon.  The career development sessions were designed to appeal to graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and newly hired faculty.  Participation in the career development sessions by the roughly 50 conferees that fall into those categories was quite good as indicated by the results of the FASEB post-meeting survey.
